awd_titl_txt: Inequalities, Symmetry, Extremality, and Multilinear Interactions
awd_abstract_narration:
Mathematical analysis provides quantitative tools that underpin other parts of mathematics (linear and nonlinear partial differential equations, numerical analysis, number theory). Among the most fundamental and widely applicable of these tools are the Fourier transform, which implements the wave-particle duality of quantum physics, and the concept of convolution.  This project brings together five themes.  (i) The quantitative natures of the Fourier transform and of convolution are expressed by various mathematical inequalities. (ii) The Fourier transform is a manifestation of certain symmetries, and in turn is governed by symmetries.  (iii) Nonlinear partial differential equations, which are ubiquitous in mathematical description of self-interacting physical systems, often involve multilinear functionals. (iv) Multilinear functionals are often governed by combinatorial issues, that is, by sophisticated counting problems. (v) Natural laws are often expressed as minimization or maximization principles. (For instance, general relativity posits that light travels along paths that are, in a sense, shortest routes between spacetime points.)  The project focuses on a circle of topics in mathematical analysis in which these themes interact. The goal is to discover and rigorously establish new inequalities, and refinements of existing inequalities.

The goal of the project is insight into linear and multilinear functionals, especially those manifesting Euclidean or other Abelian group structure.  Prototypes include the inequalities of Riesz-Sobolev, Brunn-Minkowski, Young, and Hausdorff-Young.  Both a priori upper bounds with nonexplicit constants, and inequalities with explicit optimal constants, will be investigated.  Special attention will focus on the nature and quantitative properties of functions and sets that maximize such functionals, or that nearly do so. Refined inequalities will be developed, incorporating extra terms measuring structure, rather than size; arithmetic progressions, intervals, ellipsoids, and convex sets are fundamental structural objects.  Extensions involving entropy and related quantities will be investigated.  Monotonicity of functionals under deformations will be exploited, where available.  Among the specific foci of attention are stability of Holder-Brascamp-Lieb (HBL) multilinear inequalities, variants of the Rogers-Brascamp-Lieb-Luttinger functionals under relaxed symmetry hypotheses, Schatten norms and mixed-norm versions of HBL inequalities, and multilinear inequalities for compact and discrete Abelian groups.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project has focused on inequalities in mathematical analysis, especially on multilinear inequalities in which two or more inputs, expressed as general functions, interact to produce one output. In general terms, a primary goal is to quantify the size of the output, providing an upper bound for the largest possible output, in terms of sizes of the inputs and certain of their properties. In situations with special structure, such as an underlying symmetry of the interaction, more refined goals are the precise determination of the largest possible outputs, determination of the corresponding inputs, and characterization of inputs that produce nearly maximal outputs. Nonlinear interactions arise widely in nature, in applications of mathematics to the study of nature, and in mathematics itself. This project has involved the study of certain specific types of nonlinear interactions, with the goals both of better understanding these specific topics, and of developing tools providing insight for more general questions.

The primary focus, for the latter two years of the funding period, has been placed on inequalities for multilinear oscillatory integral forms, and on associated sublevel sets. The case in which the inputs are functions of one real variable, and the space of interactions is two-dimensional, has been a productive setting for study of key phenomena present for arbitrary dimensions.  A series of research papers on these interrelated topics has been achieved. General theorems have been established for three- and four-fold multiplicative interactions. These state, in quantitative terms, that under a natural nonresonance hypothesis, highly oscillatory inputs must produce a high degree of destructive interference, and hence produce negligibly large outputs.  In resonant situations, such a conclusion is not true; the theorems reveal that there are no other, unforeseen, obstructions.  The conclusion is expressed as an inequality for the absolute value of an integral of a three- or four-fold product, integrated over a two-dimensional region, with each factor depending on a one-dimensional quantity.  Upper bounds for related additive expressions have likewise been established. The multiplicative and additive results are interrelated, and a general analytic framework has been developed using the more elementary additive theory as a tool in the multiplicative theory. Progress has been made in understanding the algebraic and combinatorial nature of the structural nonresonance assumptions on the interactions that are needed for such inequalities to be valid.  These results have consequences within Mathematics, for the theory of maximal and singular integral operators, for ergodic-theoretic results for two commuting continuous group actions, and for the existence of certain nonlinear patterns in general two-dimensional sets. Interactions of this type, with more than four factors, remain a challenge for future research.  This work is connected to both recent advances and older results in extremal and additive combinatorics.  The connection between combinatorics, multilinear inequalities, and oscillatory phenomena has been a prominent theme in mathematical analysis over the past twenty-five years, and this project has contributed to the development of that theme.


A separate line of research has concerned inequalities of Riesz-Sobolev type for certain structures with symmetries expressed through commutative group laws. These inequalities are concerned with additive interactions of pairs of source sets, quantifying the extent to which the resulting additive outputs can be focused within a general target region of specified size. Results achieved generalize the special cases understood through prior work, including characterization of pairs of sources and targets that maximize additive interactions, and characterizion in quantitative terms of those that nearly maximize such interactions.


Progress on other research topics has been achieved. Firstly, examples have been constructed of infinite-dimensional spaces of functions, with the property that any two functions whose absolute values are nearly equal, are themselves nearly equal up to unimodular constant factors. This is motivated, loosely, by crystallography, where the quantity experimentally measured is the absolute value of the quantity of interest.  Secondly, a sharp inequality in mixed Lebesgue norms has been formulated and established for solutions of the linear Schrodinger wave equation, globally in time, in the one spatial dimension periodic setting; the periodicity is the novel element of this framework. The analysis involves multilinear oscillatory interactions. Thirdly, sharpened forms of Young's convolution inequality have been studied for Euclidean and Heisenberg groups, obtaining a quantitative characterization of pairs of inputs with specified Lebesgue norms, the Lebesgue norm  of whose convolution is nearly maximal. Fourthly, the effect of dropping the key symmetry hypothesis of the classical symmetrization inequality of Rogers-Brascamp-Lieb-Luttinger has been examined.  For two-dimensional interactions that are small perturbations of symmetric ones, maximizing sets have been shown to exist, and to be small perturbations of ellipses.
